revised_title: On the Motion of a Plate of Metal and Ice on Inclined Planes: The Descent of Glaciers
tldr: The author conducted experiments with a plate of metal and ice on inclined planes to study their motion when dilated and contracted due to temperature changes. They found that the coefficient of expansion of ice is nearly twice as great as the coefficient of dilatation of lead, and more than twice as great as that of any other solid. The author also explained the formation of transverse and lateral crevasses in glaciers and the fact that a glacier crushes itself through a gorge. These findings contribute to our understanding of the mechanics of glacier motion.
